unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about loan repayments… Honestly, figuring out EMI is like trying to understand why Bollywood songs exist. No logic, just drama.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about loan repayments… Honestly, figuring out E-M-I is like trying to understand why Bollywood songs exist. No logic, just drama.

unnormalised: Let’s say Sharmaji took a personal loan of ₹5,00,000 from SBI at 12% interest p.a. for 5 years. Now, the bank guy will flash you an EMI amount, something like ₹11,122 per month. Sounds reasonable, right? Wrong! He’s conveniently skipping the part where for the first 2 years, basically all you're paying is interest. You're basically fattening the bank's wallet while your principal sits there, giggling.
normalised: Let’s say Sharmaji took a personal loan of rupee five hundred thousand from S-B-I at twelve percent interest per annum for five years. Now, the bank guy will flash you an E-M-I amount, something like rupee eleven thousand one hundred and twenty two per month. Sounds reasonable, right? Wrong! He’s conveniently skipping the part where for the first two years, basically all you're paying is interest. You're basically fattening the bank's wallet while your principal sits there, giggling.

unnormalised: My chacha got a loan of Rs. 10,00,000 to buy a flat in Gurgaon. He thought he was being smart by opting for a longer tenure, something like 20 years. EMI was lower, only Rs. 8,000 per month. What he didn’t realise (and neither did I, tbh, until my wife explained it using diagrams and flowcharts) is that he’d end up paying, like, Rs. 25,00,000 in interest. That's enough to buy *another* flat, assuming you can find anything decent in Gurgaon for that price, which is like finding a unicorn riding an auto-rickshaw.
normalised: My chacha got a loan of rupee one million to buy a flat in Gurgaon. He thought he was being smart by opting for a longer tenure, something like twenty years. E-M-I was lower, only rupee eight thousand per month. What he didn’t realise (and neither did I, to be honest, until my wife explained it using diagrams and flowcharts) is that he’d end up paying, like, rupee two point five million in interest. That's enough to buy *another* flat, assuming you can find anything decent in Gurgaon for that price, which is like finding a unicorn riding an auto-rickshaw.

unnormalised: Then there's the pre-payment penalty drama. Some banks, especially the sarkari ones, still charge a fee if you want to prepay your loan early. Seriously? You're trying to give them *back* their money and they penalize you for it? It's like inviting guests for dinner and then charging them for breathing your air. So, before signing on the dotted line, quiz the bank guy about prepayment charges. If he starts humming Bollywood songs and avoiding eye contact, run.

So, before signing on the dotted line, quiz the bank guy about prepayment charges. If he starts humming Bollywood songs and avoiding eye contact, run.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on the fine print. It’s written in font size -2, in Sanskrit, and probably requires a PhD in astrophysics to decipher. You need to hire a lawyer, a translator, and maybe even a priest to bless the document before you sign it. Always ask about hidden charges, processing fees (which are basically free money for the bank), and late payment penalties. A penalty of Rs. 500 might seem small, but they add up faster than Delhi traffic.
normalised: And don't even get me started on the fine print. It’s written in font size minus two, in Sanskrit, and probably requires a P-H-D in astrophysics to decipher. You need to hire a lawyer, a translator, and maybe even a priest to bless the document before you sign it. Always ask about hidden charges, processing fees (which are basically free money for the bank), and late payment penalties. A penalty of rupee five hundred might seem small, but they add up faster than Delhi traffic.

unnormalised: Moral of the story? Treat loan repayments like you treat spicy pani puri. Enjoy it responsibly. Don't get so caught up in the "low EMI" fantasy that you end up regretting it later. Calculate the total interest payable, negotiate prepayment options, and read the fine print (with magnifying glass and decoder ring if necessary).

unnormalised: P.S. I'm not a financial advisor, I’m just a guy who’s made a lot of mistakes with money. This is just friendly advice from a fellow sufferer. Proceed with caution, and maybe consult a real expert before you take that loan of Rs 20,00,000 to fund your start-up! Good luck, and may the EMI gods be ever in your favor. Remember to check those interest rates again; the rate might jump to 15% p.a. unexpectedly!
